Posts.Content: I also went that route for 2 years, and in the end was happy I acted when I did. I initially considered brachytherapy, but when my PSA jumped over 10 I no longer was a candidate. At your age, you also have a higher risk of bladder cancer and other complications down the road if you choose brachy or radiation; a thought worth considering. The side effects of hormone treatment therapy, usually prescribed with radiation, are also worth looking into. The bottom line is no one can predict with complete accuracy what the cancer is doing once you've found it. Until final pathology after a radical procedure it's still an estimate. My initial diagnosis of GS 3+3 turned out to be a GS 4+3 and 15% of the gland was involved. It was comforting to know the extent of the cancer once I decided to have it removed completely as it reinforced that my final decision was valid. Best of luck with whatever you decide. Bill

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Shinytop Dr did dre first, said all was normal. Did the ultrasound, said normal prostate is about 30 grams, mine was 140. He commented that may be the reason for the upturn in PSA. Now the wait for the biopsy, 12 cores, results. When I was discussing biopsy results with my surgeon he talked about the size of the prostrate with respect to the percentages of cancer found in the cores. He stated that if the the percent discovered in each core of a biopsy from a small prostate were the same as that of a large prostate, and an equal number of cores were sampled; then it MAY indicate a more severe case of cancer with the large prostate because there is more tissue to work with and less tissue taken as a percentage of the whole gland. This made sense since I had normal DRE and my prostate was a normal size at 28 grams. Stated differently: If my prostate were 140 grams they'd have to take 5 times the cores for an equivalent sampling. Not sure if this is ever considered, but worth a brief discussion when determining the extent of cancer that MAY be present. This was discussed without regard to the fact that enlarged prostates more often cause increased PSA results. Bill

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kat719 From your experience how much does the 6 wk post op PSA results differ from the next one and the one after? Kat719, The half life of PSA is 2-3 days; that is the time it takes for the PSA to decrease by 50%. PSA is only produced by prostate tissue so if the prostate is totally removed there is no more generation of prostate specific antigen (PSA). It is generally accepted that after 6 weeks post op that the PSA readings should be zero and remain such if the operation was successful in removing all the prostate tissue and the cancer has not spread. A reading preceded by a negative or another symbol indicates the lowest measurable amount that can be determined by that mode of testing, therefore a −0.01 does not mean that there is a 0.01 measurement, only that they can't determine anything lower than that. Bill

Also found a huge number of foods could contribute like chocolate, some fruits, and many more, but haven't paid any attention to them. I admit I probably started to run a little early, but my docs said it would be OK. Bill

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RickRed52 In Aug one month prior to prostate cancer awareness month I tried to get our local newspaper to do a story about prostate cancer. They wouldn't do it. I tried three other times, each time I failed. For months I'd read the paper and be annoyed at the number of stories I felt were much less important than the story I wanted our paper to print. So last month I sent an e-mail directly to the Modesto Bee Editor. I was shocked within a week I'd been contacted by a reporter. This is a link to the story that appears on the front page of the Modesto Bee on 12/16/13. There was much more I'd hoped they print, but I was pleased with the article: http://www.modbee.com/2013/12/15/309...-prostate.html Congratulations, Rick, great idea. I live in Reno now, but left mine in Burlington, VT.

Posts.Title: It's taken me a year to get our local newspaper to do a story about prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by malbaby I am still suffering from urinary frequency and urgency 14 months post bracchytheraphy. I take flowmax, but that only helps with the urine flow. Has anyone taken any medication or natural remedy that is effective? Spasms of the bladder and urinary tract can be caused by irritants & inflammation and manifest themselves as urinary frequency or urgency. Brachytherapy or seeds release their radiation over time and one of the major side effects is a burning and a feeling of urgency. Ditropan or Ditropan XL (generic name: Oxybutynin) is an effective antispasmodic used to treat spasms of the bladder and may give you some relief. You my want to discuss the duration of release of the radiation from the seeds with your Radiologist and ask him if that may be the reason for your discomfort; and whether this is a valid treatment for what you're experiencing.

Posts.Content: There's a nerve in the pelvic floor, not sure its name, that is close to the prostate and innervates the lower extremities. If it is affected it can result in ankle discomfort and pain. I expect the radiation, even though it is supposed to be specific, also affects the surrounding tissue including the nerves that trigger other parts of the body. Sorry I have no solutions for you, but you may want to pursue this type of logic for treatments, if any.

Posts.Title: Hip and leg pain could it be from Radation. Treatment

Posts.Content: Fran, I was doing the AS and since I had no history of PSA prior to 63 years old I was at a disadvantage. When PSA doubles in one year or less it's problematic. Since my core samplings were so slight, PSA below 10, DRE normal with no irregularities, and Gleason 6 they wanted to watch my numbers for developments. When the PSA jumped from 8.4 to 12.4, coupled with a family (father) history of the disease and positive diagnosis everything was accelerated. In retrospect, I could have acted earlier, but the initial results from my surgeon and the post-op pathology is that I acted soon enough. On another front, I found a survey that looked at long term follow-ups of RRP patients and it makes me wonder at all about the validity of AS. In the study the results after 18.6 years of watching PSA values of individuals 65 years old or higher, who had RRP found that those with Gleason 6 scores had 4% incidence of recurring PSA while those with Gleason 7 scores had 45% incidence. My thought, which I also will be asking my urologist/surgeon about, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer will give you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This would contradict the validity of AS altogether. To answer your question: I relied on all the crap statistics, including those articles in media releases from the NY Times and others, that minimized DRE & PSA for all age groups based on morbidity and mortality rates vs un-tested and untreated subjects. My cousin fell within the timeframe when this controversy was at its height. His physician did not inform him of either a nodule on DRE or increasing PSA values happening for 2 years, and once he had the RRP found it had spread outside the gland. His life has changed for the worse as he continues with treatment and issues. Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: I am 3 weeks out from Davinci RP and had the catheter removed after 2 weeks with no issues. At 65 years old I was active as a runner and biker prior to surgery. I have absolutely no bladder control, dribble constantly, and without using a male urinal during the evening, would be wetting everything every night. I did Kegel prior to surgery and am doing them now, but don't seem to be making any progress. I have not asked my surgeon about the sphincters yet, but will do so next week at my appointment. I've read other posts and wonder if i'm in the minority with respect to incontinence success or should I expect better results.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> At 65 years old I was active

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: Fran, Quite frustrating. I did find it much more convenient to sleep with the male urinal. As soon as I become erect I have no control and cannot make it to the bathroom. Tried holding my penis, but the pressure caused it to act like a wild hose before I reached the toilet so the urinal gives me some sanity and sleep. I've been walking 5-6 miles during the day and can't retain anything, but doing a kegel while sitting down allows me to trickle once I reach the toilet provided I don't wait too long. I guess it's baby steps. Posts.Content: Fran, I was doing the AS and since I had no history of PSA prior to 63 years old I was at a disadvantage. When PSA doubles in one year or less it's problematic. Since my core samplings were so slight, PSA below 10, DRE normal with no irregularities, and Gleason 6 they wanted to watch my numbers for developments. When the PSA jumped from 8.4 to 12.4, coupled with a family (father) history of the disease and positive diagnosis everything was accelerated. In retrospect, I could have acted earlier, but the initial results from my surgeon and the post-op pathology is that I acted soon enough. On another front, I found a survey that looked at long term follow-ups of RRP patients and it makes me wonder at all about the validity of AS. In the study the results after 18.6 years of watching PSA values of individuals 65 years old or higher, who had RRP found that those with Gleason 6 scores had 4% incidence of recurring PSA while those with Gleason 7 scores had 45% incidence. My thought, which I also will be asking my urologist/surgeon about, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer will give you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This would contradict the validity of AS altogether. To answer your question: I relied on all the crap statistics, including those articles in media releases from the NY Times and others, that minimized DRE & PSA for all age groups based on morbidity and mortality rates vs un-tested and untreated subjects. My cousin fell within the timeframe when this controversy was at its height. His physician did not inform him of either a nodule on DRE or increasing PSA values happening for 2 years, and once he had the RRP found it had spread outside the gland. His life has changed for the worse as he continues with treatment and issues. Posts.Content: Fran, Quite frustrating. I did find it much more convenient to sleep with the male urinal. As soon as I become erect I have no control and cannot make it to the bathroom. Tried holding my penis, but the pressure caused it to act like a wild hose before I reached the toilet so the urinal gives me some sanity and sleep. I've been walking 5-6 miles during the day and can't retain anything, but doing a kegel while sitting down allows me to trickle once I reach the toilet provided I don't wait too long. I guess it's baby steps. Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: I am 3 weeks out from Davinci RP and had the catheter removed after 2 weeks with no issues. At 65 years old I was active as a runner and biker prior to surgery. I have absolutely no bladder control, dribble constantly, and without using a male urinal during the evening, would be wetting everything every night. I did Kegel prior to surgery and am doing them now, but don't seem to be making any progress. I have not asked my surgeon about the sphincters yet, but will do so next week at my appointment. I've read other posts and wonder if i'm in the minority with respect to incontinence success or should I expect better results.

Posts.Content: I'm signed up to run a 200 mile-6 person relay race at the end of September, and will do it even if I still have to use pads or diapers so as not to soil the van. You're as young as you make yourself feel. Dwell on it and it will age you. I don't run as fast as I did in my 40's, and don't expect to have the same enthusiasm for other things I did earlier in life, but I expect to do as much as I can whenever I can until I can't.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: Best of luck, Kargok9, with whatever decision you decide to make. I had similar numbers and tried, without any significant success, lifestyle changes in hopes of changing my numbers and avoid the inevitable. They did not work and only prolonged the inevitable. I stayed away from my bike prior to PSA tests, altered my diet, increased my aerobic work and my numbers still increased at a steady rate. I know mine was not a study, but I searched to get an idea of the effect of biking and exercise on PSA and could not find anything that supported it scientifically. In my case, the AS route allowed my PSA to exceed 10 and eliminate my choice of Brachytherapy as an option. I chose surgery and feel I am fortunate to have made the decision when I did. It gave me a definite idea of the severity of my condition and an outlook at what the end-game would look like without having to worry about increasing side effects and long term symptoms that may crop up. Know that your decision is yours alone and your individual situation is yours alone, but that decision is the one you'll have to take with you as you navigate the quagmire. Bill

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Incontinence

Posts.Content: Andy, Chuck & Fran have given an excellent view of what you have, or have not. The internal sphincter is heavily involved with the prostate and bladder so, in most cases, is hard to spare when doing a radical. I'm 9 weeks out, 7 from the catheter & have leaked all the time. With the catheter in I felt so much was leaking around it that something was wrong, and to date I have had little improvement other than, as Fran mentioned, sitting and kegaling into the bathroom. I'm told this is 'not uncommon'. I have a system with the pads, but hope to wake some morning and have full control. I do sleep with a male urinal and use it to get to the bathroom which allows me to avoid dripping. I hope your recovery is more rapid than mine which is the extreme, but realize the worst is over and things should get better with time. Bill

Know that your decision is yours alone and your individual situation is yours alone, but that decision is the one you'll have to take with you as you navigate the quagmire. Bill

Gabka, Unfortunately, you're resigned to sit and wait for the PSA result as nothing more can be done to determine the success of your husbands operation. I would say, from the quotes I noted, you're in pretty good shape, so since you have to do the waiting game, stay positive and deal with what's at hand. Pressing on the wall is not going through it!! Best wishes for those chips falling the right way. Bill

Posts.Title: My husbands prostete cancer

Posts.Content: Andy, Chuck & Fran have given an excellent view of what you have, or have not. The internal sphincter is heavily involved with the prostate and bladder so, in most cases, is hard to spare when doing a radical. I'm 9 weeks out, 7 from the catheter & have leaked all the time. With the catheter in I felt so much was leaking around it that something was wrong, and to date I have had little improvement other than, as Fran mentioned, sitting and kegaling into the bathroom. I'm told this is 'not uncommon'. I have a system with the pads, but hope to wake some morning and have full control. I do sleep with a male urinal and use it to get to the bathroom which allows me to avoid dripping. I hope your recovery is more rapid than mine which is the extreme, but realize the worst is over and things should get better with time. Bill

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chasgrips45 This was after surgery in 2011 with a gleason 8 cancer. I went for 9mos before recurrence. At .2 I decided to undergo 37 treatments of radiation at a clinic in Sylva N.C. I waited 3 mos ,went & got my psa checked & this was the result. They must have used some new super duper testing apparatus . I thought they could`nt detect any psa below a certain level. I sure hope it lasts for awhile. My next test will be in 3 mos I guess. My clinician told me that if the PSA reading is preceded by '<' then that is as low as the test can accurately determine the reading to be. That is a reading of <0.01 means in essence zero and would indicate the ultra sensitive PSA test was performed.

Posts.Content: I was given the following 8 week Kegel Exercise Chart to be performed 2 times daily: The total number can be divided up over the course of the entire day. QC=Quick Contractions & SC=Short contractions Week 1: 5QC, 10 of 3 sec SC, 5QC Week 2: 10QC, 15 of 4 sec SC, 10QC Week 3: 15QC, 10 of 5 sec SC, 15QC Week 4: 15QC, 20 of 10sec SC, 15QC Week 5: 20QC, 25 of 10sec SC, 20QC Week 6: 30QC, 30 of 10sec SC, 30QC Week 7: 40QC, 40 of 10sec SC, 40QC Week 8: 50QC, 50 of 10sec SC, 50QC I started 2 weeks post op after the catheter was removed and am only now, after 4 weeks of kegels, only at the start of recovery as I am able to stay dry at bedtime and occasionally make it to the toilet during the day. I do see some improvement, although slight.

Posts.Title: Kegals

Posts.Content: Mike, You may want to check a thread that several people responded to with regards to Kegels and Incontinence: http://www.cancerforums.net/threads/...048#post199048 I did them pre-op and am doing them now, post-op with varying success. I found out that the Internal Sphincter (closest to the bladder) was probably the one I was isolating pre-op and since that is now removed I have to rely on the Exterior Sphincter which was not my main control mechanism before my radical prostatectomy. I was also given a schedule of kegals for 8 weeks starting after the operation. It was twice per day and increased in intensity as time went on. It is a muscle, and it only makes sense that you can fatigue it, but also train it. Squeezing yur buttocks does not isolate the sphincter of the urethra which is what you want to control. I believe the easiest way to feel this sphincter is during urination and then practicing contracting it once you have isolated it. I leaked continually while with the catheter and up until the present. I'm 6 weeks out and only now am seeing slight results, but you'll find that is quite individualized. My best advice, as obtained from the many supportive entries here, is be a patient patient. Best of luck. Bill

Posts.Content: All, I just updated my signature and my most recent PSA score. The incontinence issues are slowly resolving, and I am relieved with my results. Posts.Content: I am a runner and did so as soon as I could after my RALP. I was running as much as 7 days per week and 6 miles per day and continued to bleed up to 13 weeks. The discomfort was not bothersome, but the bleeding seemed unnatural. I was scoped and my surgeon showed me the micro bleeding that was occurring around my sutures that he said were designed to dissolve in 3-4 months. Only running caused bleeding and at 13 weeks it abruptly stopped. Could the sutures possibly be causing the stress and discomfort?

Posts.Title: 6 weeks post ralp

Posts.Content: Centsible, You're at the start of your journey, but know that you'll have improvement and it will take time. I am 10 months out and still wear pads. I saw my surgeon last week and he said that active individuals have the most difficulty regaining continence and potency. One study I read showed 95% recovery after 1 year, 67% after 6 months, and 33% after 3 months. I am a runner and biker and had the most difficulty when I exercised and actually had bleeding from the disposable stitches until 13 weeks when they finally dissolved. Pads are still in my life. My surgeon explained that the interior sphincter is heavily involved in the prostate gland and integrated into the pelvic floor so its removal and weakening the surrounding tissue is a given. Best wishes, we here on the forum hope you have a speedy and uneventful recovery from symptoms, but focus on the big picture and being cancer free. Bill

Posts.Title: Post Op recovery, what is the real time

Posts.Content: I can't give you any more information than already stated, but I can offer a perspective of what you may go through. I'm almost 6 weeks post op after having GS6 readings on two biopsies. I am quite relieved I had the procedure when I did in light of the final pathology. It will be stated that the three major concerns that evolve with PC, in order of importance are: 1. Get rid of the cancer 2. Regain continence 3. Avoid impotence I am struggling with incontinence and have not seen much improvement since day one. I wish I would have had a more detailed discussion with my surgeon about internal sphincter sparing, but this comes with the territory. My situation is a minority sector and most have more positive results more quickly. Don't underestimate the value of obtaining all the information you can prior to making your decision. Best of luck with your journey. The path is not without bumps, but it is better than jumping off the cliff.

Now after week 10 I am dry all day with just a drip when I try to lift something heavy, and even then I can stop it. So at 6 weeks, just keep up the kegel's and hopefully you will start seeing rapid improvement. Seems to improve weekly as opposed to daily, just an observation.Lance Lance, Thanks for the encouragement, I've been running and that seems to put me backwards as I bleed after 2 miles, but I had an erection this morning, just shy of 6 weeks post-op. I think all the pre-op kegels only strengthened the sphincter at the bladder that they removed, and now my kegels for what's left are of marginal effectiveness. Just think, every day post-op something new crops up (no pun intended).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lLance WJW, hang in there, it will get better. At 3 weeks I was dry, but by 6 weeks I was leaking like a sieve. It has been up & down. Now after week 10 I am dry all day with just a drip when I try to lift something heavy, and even then I can stop it. So at 6 weeks, just keep up the kegel's and hopefully you will start seeing rapid improvement. Seems to improve weekly as opposed to daily, just an observation.Lance Lance, Thanks for the encouragement, I've been running and that seems to put me backwards as I bleed after 2 miles, but I had an erection this morning, just shy of 6 weeks post-op. I think all the pre-op kegels only strengthened the sphincter at the bladder that they removed, and now my kegels for what's left are of marginal effectiveness. Just think, every day post-op something new crops up (no pun intended).

Posts.Title: New to this: clinical T2 prostate cancer Gleason 3+4 = 7/10 and 3+3 = 6/10

Posts.Content: Centsible, You're at the start of your journey, but know that you'll have improvement and it will take time. I am 10 months out and still wear pads. I saw my surgeon last week and he said that active individuals have the most difficulty regaining continence and potency. One study I read showed 95% recovery after 1 year, 67% after 6 months, and 33% after 3 months. I am a runner and biker and had the most difficulty when I exercised and actually had bleeding from the disposable stitches until 13 weeks when they finally dissolved. Pads are still in my life. My surgeon explained that the interior sphincter is heavily involved in the prostate gland and integrated into the pelvic floor so its removal and weakening the surrounding tissue is a given. Best wishes, we here on the forum hope you have a speedy and uneventful recovery from symptoms, but focus on the big picture and being cancer free. Bill

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: I'm a runner and started back 5 weeks post surgery. I had bleeding every time I ran for 13 weeks. I was concerned, and questioned my surgeon who finally did a scope and verified that it was one of the sutures that had not dissolved. He reassured me there was not an issue, and when the sutures dissolved fully at 3-4 months the bleeding would stop; and it did. He never was concerned about the bleeding from the beginning, and said it was a normal healing process. The scope, however, set me back a month in the incontinence arena. Bill

Posts.Title: Bleeding post DaVinci surgery

Posts.Content: Not sure if this helps, but I am the poster boy for bleeding. I'm 3 months out and still have bleeding. It happens only when I run, which I do on a regular basis. My surgeon wanted to be sure it wasn't a severe problem as he told me I could do whatever I was comfortable with, so he went in with a scope last week to make sure. The bleeding was located around or near the self dissolving sutures which he said were in the process of deteriorating. They are designed to last 3-4 months. Everything else looked perfect and he said I should notice improvement once they dissolve fully. He was never concerned and told me the bleeding was proportional to activity and since the incision was healed it was only a 'minor inconvenience' that will correct in time. The cytology that was done 2 weeks post op and prior to catheter removal was the determining factor in showing proper healing. After 6 weeks I was released to do physically whatever I was comfortable doing.

Posts.Title: Bleeding post DaVinci surgery

Posts.Content: Leo, I went for two years trying everything to avoid the inevitable. I played with the PSA and altered my biking, sex, diet, and exercise thinking any one of them may have been contributing to the increase. The biopsy showed I had PCa and the increasing PSA indicated something was developing which was confirmed once the final pathology was performed after the prostate was removed. My two biopsies were not an issue at all, not even slight discomfort although I did have bloody semen for several weeks. Looking back at my journey the biopsies shed the needed light on why I had abnormal PSA readings and made my decision that much easier. Best of luck and know there are are good outcomes out there, but don't hide from the issues. I lived with it for 2 years and am thankful I acted when I did. Had I not listened to advice and logical thinking, I may not have had such a positive result. Bill

Posts.Title: Should I do a Prostate Biopsy ? are my chances for recovery better if diagnosed early

Posts.Content: I found a survey that looked at long term follow-ups of over 700 RRP patients to try to determine the optimal time patients undergoing radical prostatectomies should be monitored. The results make me wonder about the validity of AS once cancer has been discovered. In the study the results after 18.6 years of watching PSA values of individuals 65 years old or higher, who had undergone RRP, found that those with Gleason 6 scores had 4% incidence of recurring PSA while those with Gleason 7 scores had 45% incidence. My thought, which I also will be discussing with my urologist/surgeon, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer gives you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. I went this route, had a higher Gleason on post-op pathology (a common occurrence), and wonder if I am now at risk of falling into the higher risk group later in life.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance (AS)

Posts.Content: Lance & Fran, I mis-spoke when I said I had no bowel control. What I meant to say was I have no bladder control. Like Fran, I can make it to the bathroom with forethought and kegel, but otherwise spend most days changing briefs. I've tried doing the kegel at night when I have to empty the bladder, but to no avail. I'm discarding up to 200ml each trip about 3 times per night. As soon as I'm erect it flows into the urinal. Lance, I was curious about the bike and probably will only look at it for at least 8 weeks. I am able to walk 5-6 miles daily and actually ran a bit yesterday, but not sure if that's helping as I return home with a soggy brief each day. Appetite, bowels, sleep, energy all seem to have returned to normal without incident. Cath removal was 14 days post op so I'm hoping I'm on track for the next hurdles. Trying to be a patient patient. Bill

Posts.Title: 6 Weeks Post Op

Posts.Content: Don't worry about not doing the kegels pre-op. I did them religiously and think I only ended up strengthening the sphincter that they removed as I had and still have very little control. Not sure I could isolate the external sphincter while the other one was doing the work, but now I work kegels daily hoping to get better control. I'm at the 6 week mark and have past the first step only-ie. I am able to get through the night without wetting a pad by using a male urinal when I become erect. Otherwise I have very limited control. I walked in the hospital, and after the catheter was removed (2 weeks post-op) regularly walked 6 miles per day, but not sure it has helped with the urinary control although I feel great otherwise. Best of luck with your procedure, each day after is another growing curve.

Posts.Content: Brian, I was in a very similar situation and waited for 2 years before treatment. I originally considered Brachytherapy, but when my PSA jumped over 10 it was no longer an option. I was not enthused about the long term side effect prospects of radiation so eventually decided on a radical. I was relieved in the end as the final pathology determined I had a more aggressive form than originally thought. Also, don't underestimate the psychological effects on those close to you if you decide to go the AS route. Best of luck with whatever decision you make. It seems that you caught it early enough and should have a positive outcome. Bill

Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon This request is on behalf of a friend who had prostate surgery and also ended up with surgery for an umbilical surgery. Unfortunately he has been incontinent for 20 months (He is 75). Has anyone experienced incontinence this long and had something done to help the situation.? Thanks in advance B I'm 6 months out and still having problems. Things have improved gradually, but I still leak throughout the day. I am able to control the major urination for the most part. I read a statistical study from a Urologist with well over 1000 patients who quoted continence levels at 3 months, 6months, and 1 year and noted 66% and 95% for the latter two. I place myself on the other side of the 66% category and hope for a full recovery in the near future, but am told to be patient. My cousin had the same surgery and is over 2 years out with a similar problem. He has been prescribed a month of active Kegel exercising before he is referred to a specialist to explore options; one of which would be the artificial sphincter. Bill

Posts.Content: Once you're on an IV drip they'll pump in enough fluid and nutrition to get you through the first couple of days. They didn't let me out until I had a bowel movement so they could be sure I didn't have any blockages. Prior to the op I drank gatorade (red was not allowed) and got through with no issues. Had jello also, but it wasn't too appealing.

Posts.Title: Just recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I found a survey that looked at long term follow-ups of over 700 RRP patients to try to determine the optimal time patients undergoing radical prostatectomies should be monitored. The results make me wonder about the validity of AS once cancer has been discovered. In the study the results after 18.6 years of watching PSA values of individuals 65 years old or higher, who had undergone RRP, found that those with Gleason 6 scores had 4% incidence of recurring PSA while those with Gleason 7 scores had 45% incidence. My thought, which I also will be discussing with my urologist/surgeon, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer gives you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. I went this route, had a higher Gleason on post-op pathology (a common occurrence), and wonder if I am now at risk of falling into the higher risk group later in life.

I'm of the opinion, in hind sight, that cancer is cancer regardless of the score; and sooner rather than later action is probably a better option.

Posts.Content: Chuck, I couldn't eat after 4PM the day prior to my 1PM operation and used an enema the morning of and drank a bottle of Magnesium Citrate at 4PM the day prior. Posts.Title: question about clear liquid diet

Posts.Content: Once you're on an IV drip they'll pump in enough fluid and nutrition to get you through the first couple of days. They didn't let me out until I had a bowel movement so they could be sure I didn't have any blockages. Prior to the op I drank gatorade (red was not allowed) and got through with no issues. Had jello also, but it wasn't too appealing.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Here's something else for you to know: A number of years ago, Johns Hopkins did a study of true Gleason 6 patients (those who turned out to truly be only Gleason 6 with no higher grade tumors). The study involved 17,000 Gleason 6 patients who underwent a prostatectomy. And the number of cases where they found any metastasis was absolutely ZERO. Not even one. Jebstart, Don't get too crazy over the numbers, try to focus on the end game. There's no exact way to determine what the situation is until you get in there, only determinations based on history. Once you decide on a therapy route and carry through you'll be relieved you made the decision; regardless of the decision you made. Bill

Posts.Content: Sciatica is a pinching of the sciatic nerve and usually manifests itself as a sharp pain sometimes running down the leg. The psoas muscle is one of the largest ones in the body and starts at the spinal column and runs through the hip and into the groin. It supports most all of the movements of the upper body and as such is susceptible to all sorts of strains and sprains. When it is injured it can cause lower back pain, hip pain, and/or groin pain. Lower back pain is a very common issue and can be caused by any number of activities. Not so sure prostate issues start there and the burning urine should indicate some sort or treatment or inquiries.

My thought, is that waiting for treatment after positive diagnosis of cancer may give you a higher probability of increasing Gleason score thus a higher probability of cancer returning. This seems to contradict the validity of AS altogether. I went this route, had a higher Gleason on post-op pathology (a common occurrence), and wonder if I am at a higher risk later in life because i did AS.

Posts.Content: JD1969, Here's a copy of an email I sent Fran who was interested in my progress: It's over & I survived. The race was a 196.2 mile 6 person relay race from Saratoga Springs,NY to Lake Placid,NY through some pretty rough mountainous terrain. It took us 29.5 hours from Friday morning to Saturday afternoon. We each ran 6 legs ranging from 3-9 miles. Average distance varied per person from 30-38 miles. We actually took 12 minutes off our time from last year when we won the 40 an under age group. (One guy under 40 puts us in that bracket!) Not sure of the final results this year as it takes a few week to tabulate. I am still relatively incontinent and remain so, but that was part of the experiment. As you may remember, I bleed during every run, regardless of distance and did so through the first 4 of my 6 legs. The last two had little, if any blood and only slight urine as I became somewhat dehydrated. I did use way more pads than I had predicted which was natural given the circumstances. As far as conditioning: I was in great shape going into the operation on July 16th and was not able to start training again in ernest for 6 weeks post-op. (2 weeks of catheter, 2 weeks of normal recovery and 2 weeks of 'trying' to regain composure with walking/very light jogging led me to the 6 weeks.) I feel I regained over 90% of my fitness before the race which was 11 weeks post op including my last week of tapering. I would have liked 1-2 more weeks as I only recently felt I was getting back to full strength As far as rehab: I am now taking 1-2 weeks off to see if the running hampered my recovery from incontinence. I will try to monitor it and be more vigilant with kegal exercising. In retrospect, I feel that the event helped me focus and try to put the post-op symptoms on the back burner of my life. I function pretty well with pads and have been able to resume a normal life style considering the trauma of cancer and major surgery. Hope this wasn't too lengthy, but that's the way it unfolded for me. Stay the course. Bill p.s. My two surgeons are both distance runners and told me to do whatever I was comfortable with. They said the bleeding would not hurt me as I had healed at the incision. I was able to get to 35+ miles per week running and they told me it was OK to bike at 8 weeks although I stayed off the bike. Since you're a month behind me and much younger I'd say get out and go for it-It's time

Posts.Title: How long before I can start working out/bike riding etc.

Posts.Content: My point is that there are three accepted possibilities for increased PSA readings: Prostate Cancer Prostatitis Age (minor changes are normal) The peripheral reasons are speculative. I agree, Chuck, it is sensible to avoid bike riding, sex, and DRE prior to blood draw, but probably not imperative. Bill

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Not totally sure about radiation, having had surgery, but do recall a few points in researching my options. I was told by my radiologist that Brachytherapy releases the same amount of radiation as is given by Beam Therapy, only it is released from the seeds over time. Either choice can damage surrounding tissue which is why the symptoms and long term effects of radiation are one of the down sides of this treatment. Radiation also destroys the prostate tissue, but this too happens over time which is probably why the PSA readings should be more accurate after the treatment. Sorry I can't answer your question since I'm not sure what that time-frame is.

Posts.Title: How long does it take?

Posts.Content: I've often seen advice that bike riding should not be done prior to taking PSA tests as it could affect the results. I've discussed this with my urologist and surgeon, and searched the internet for confirmation, but cannot verify the validity of the suggestion. Personally, I tried either riding and not riding before my tests and the PSA showed a relatively linear increase regardless. Obviously, I know this is not a scientific conclusion, but my simple observation. It would make sense that sex prior to drawing blood for the test could affect the results since the prostate produces seminal fluid and emits it during ejaculation. Logic would dictate there could be an increase since the gland is traumatized through contraction. Again, I couldn't find a valid study where this is problematic. The validity for not performing a DRE prior to testing postulates that trauma to the prostate may render increased PSA results. Not sure if this has been determined scientifically either, but most doctors practice it. There was a survey sent to a running club and a biking club in Boston to try to determine the effect of biking &/or running on male impotence and the results came back inconclusive and statistically insignificant. This was not a true scientific study, but I believe over 500 recipients from each group responded. It was an effort to discover whether further study could or should be conducted for this purpose. What I'm suggesting is we shouldn't be offering false hope for high PSA results to readers of this blog without scientific evidence. Correct me if I'm wrong or off task here, or at least let this be a thread for discussion. Bill

We in this 'club' are, in a strange way, stronger for dealing with this, and hopefully it has given us a better outlook on what life means to us and those that surround us. Thanks to everyone on the Forum that have been so supportive this past year. Best wishes for a happy New Year. Bill

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: My point is that there are three accepted possibilities for increased PSA readings: Prostate Cancer Prostatitis Age (minor changes are normal) The peripheral reasons are speculative. I agree, Chuck, it is sensible to avoid bike riding, sex, and DRE prior to blood draw, but probably not imperative. Bill

Posts.Title: Bike riding, DRE, & sexual activity effects on PSA

Posts.Content: Ronny, My understanding is that the open procedure has a slightly higher potential for infection, and requires an extra week for recovery. I also read that a resume for a robotic surgeon including several years of performing the open procedure would be a plus. I'm not sure about this, but from a small segment of people I know who have had the open procedure the incontinence issues were less than those that had the robotic procedure. You may want to ask your surgeon if he is more likely to spare the internal sphincter if it is an open procedure. The reality is that nearly 85% of prostatectomy procedures use the robot which probably has an economic element as well as the promotion that they can more easily spare the nerves responsible for erections. Either way, the surgeon is the limiting factor. If you're looking for the least traumatic procedure, and the one that you'll be able to handle with no outside help you should consider radiation, but that brings up more issues that surely will be answered at your program. Bill

Posts.Title: Need opinions on Da vinci or radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Dan, Unfortunately, I didn't track my PSA numbers prior to 63, but you can see my plight had some similarities to yours. I did AS for 24 months and once I exceeded a PSA 10 I eliminated seeds as an option for treatment. My choice revealed, in the end, that I needed treatment and I couldn't have waited much longer. My cancer wasn't going away and I was toying with the chance it would metastasize. I am content with my decision and relieved I made the catch early enough. The critical things you have to consider is more than 3 positive cores, PSA rising over time, and GS 3+4 (>6) which indicates a more aggressive sampling. You'll find lots of examples of individuals with much lower PSA figures than you that have confirmed dangerous levels of PC. Those three parameters would dictate treatment by most clinicians, especially at your age. Best wishes with whatever you decide, but don't wait too long to delay the inevitable. Bill

Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: Jebstart, I ran a 35 mile race 9 weeks post surgery. It was a relay race and I did it in 6 legs with heavy leakage after each one. My urologist said 'active' individuals have more difficulty regaining continence, but encouraged me to exercise at whatever rate I was comfortable with. I did stay off the bike for 8 weeks, which my surgeon wanted, because of the proximity to the operation, but find that now I have less difficulty biking than running with respect to leakage. I was walking the day after surgery and continued doing it regularly until 5 weeks out when I began running again. Bill
